description: From Middle English defrauden, from Old French defrauder, from de- + frauder.

verbs.description: defraud (third-person singular simple present defrauds, present participle defrauding, simple past and past participle defrauded)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To obtain money or property from (a person) by fraud; to swindle.
examples: I had never defrauded a man of a farthing, nor called him knave behind his back. But now the last rag that covered my nakedness had been torn from me. I was branded a blackleg, card-sharper, and murderer.
Defraud ye not one the other, except it be with consent for a time, that ye may give yourselves to fasting and prayer; and come together again, that Satan tempt you not for your incontinency.
